bibl.title: Letter from Estaban Valderrama y Pena to Philip Showalter Hench, May 16, 1948

div1.p: Valderrama y Pena promises to copy items related to Cuban and American yellow fever experiments for Hench. He asserts that in June of 1900 nobody except Finlay and his assistant Delgado believed that mosquitoes transmitted yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Estaban Valderrama y Pena to Philip Showalter Hench, May 16, 1948
div1.p:
I acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 5 and I am hastening
to answer. I have orders to copy the following:

1. Copy of my picture “The triumph of Finlay”. 2. Copy of the
studies in pencil of Doctors Finlay, father and son, Walter Reed, Jesse Lazear,
James Carroll and Claudio Delgado, and of these the last one does not appear
in the picture which I made for another objective. 3. Copy of the letter of
Doctor Angles where he signs August 1, 1900. 4. Copy of two pages of the book
of Doctor Francisco Dominguez Roldan about the second American Medical Commis-
sion (the first one failed and was disbanded). It starts June 25, 1900 and
it is started the Sanarelli bacillus until the month of august. Also the in-
testinal flora. At the last they visited Doctor Finlay

I am grateful to you for your courtesy about the artistic license
but in historical matters there is no such thing. I don't believe I have
taken any licenses because always I try to document with proof from respon-
sible people. The people represented in the picture were very much discast(?) discussed
and I refuse to put Doctor Agramonte in the picture and Doctor Delgado because
the historical data found showed they were not there.

Nobody believed in June 1900 about the transmission of yellow fever
by the innoculation of a mosquito, the only one among three hundred species and
Doctor Reed was among them. Nobody believed Doctor Finlay and he had been talking
about this for many years and practicing his theory. The only faithful one was
Delgado who cooperated with him in many inoculations and saw the evidence of the
transmissions.

But there is something certain: It was to Cuba's advantage that the
Spaniards did not pay any attention to Doctor Finlay because he became more in-
dependent. It was better that the Americans were the ones to try to eliminate
the mosquito that transmitted that fever because the Americans collaborated
in our liberty and by such a great deal of good to this country. Cuba was
saved and also the rest of the world. It is worthwhile to remember this. I
am sending you a second remittance and I remain your friend and admirer.

Signed: Esteban Valderrama and Pena
P.S. Now I am a only sending you Dr. Diaz Albertini pamphlet and two clippings
from the newspapers which spoke about you.
fled under Albertini
Translated by Miss Montes
